question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
Given the function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x,y) = 8x^{1/5} y^{4/5}\end{aligned}\]

We can compute each of \(f(2x,2y)\) and \(2f(x,y)\).

\[\begin{aligned} f(2x,2y) &= 8 (2x)^{1/5} (2y)^{4/5} \\ &= 8(2)^{1/5+4/5} x^{1/5} y^{4/5} \\&= 16 x^{1/5}y^{4/5}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} 2f(x,y) &= 2(8x^{1/5}y^{4/5}) \\&= 16 x^{1/5}y^{4/5}\end{aligned}\]

And so we obtain that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(2x,2y)-2f(x,y) = 0\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Given the function
:<math>\displaystyle f(x,y) = 8x^{1/5} y^{4/5}</math>
We can compute each of <math>f(2x,2y)</math> and <math>2f(x,y)</math>.

:<math>\displaystyle\begin{align} f(2x,2y) &= 8 (2x)^{1/5} (2y)^{4/5} \\ &= 8(2)^{1/5+4/5} x^{1/5} y^{4/5} \\&= 16 x^{1/5}y^{4/5}\end{align}</math>

and

:<math>\displaystyle \begin{align}2f(x,y) &= 2(8x^{1/5}y^{4/5}) \\&= 16 x^{1/5}y^{4/5}\end{align}</math>

And so we obtain that

:<math>\displaystyle f(2x,2y)-2f(x,y) = 0 </math>
